description: For verb: borrowed from Latin probare (“to test, examine, prove”), from probus (“good”).
For noun: borrowed from Late Latin proba (“a proof”), from probare (“to test, examine, prove”); Doublet of proof. Compare Spanish tienta (“a surgeon's probe”), from tentar (“try, test”); see tempt.

definitionGroups.group: (surgery) Any of various medical instruments used to explore wounds, organs, etc. [from 15th c.]

entries.meaning: (comedy, fiction) An anal probe, a fictional instrument commonly used by aliens on abducted humans.
(figuratively) Something which penetrates something else, as though to explore; something which obtains information. [from 17th c.]
An act of probing; a prod, a poke. [from 19th c.]

examples: They launched a probe into the cause of the accident.

entries.meaning: (aeronautics) A tube attached to an aircraft which can be fitted into the drogue from a tanker aircraft to allow for aerial refuelling. [from 20th c.]
(sciences) A small device, especially an electrode, used to explore, investigate or measure something by penetrating or being placed in it. [from 20th c.]
examples: Insert the probe into the soil and read the temperature.

entries.meaning: (astronautics) A small, usually uncrewed, spacecraft used to acquire information or measurements about its surroundings. [from 20th c.]
(game of Go) a move with multiple answers seeking to make the opponent choose and commit to a strategy
(biochemistry) Any group of atoms or molecules radioactively labeled in order to study a given molecule or other structure

verbs.description: probe (third-person singular simple present probes, present participle probing, simple past and past participle probed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To explore, investigate, or question
examples: If you probe further, you may discover different reasons.
